title: Angular momentum cons - Disk B drops onto Disk A

content.question: Two uniform disks, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, each of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, have radii <math alttext="2 times uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></math> and <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, respectively. The rotational inertia of a uniform disk of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and radius <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> is <math alttext="one half lowercase m, times lowercase r squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Disk <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> rotates in a horizontal plane about its center with angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and Disk <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is initially held at rest. Disk <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is then released and falls onto the center of Disk <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> such that both disks spin together about their centers without slipping. What is the angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> of the two-disk system?
